#Text=The Eye of Apollo

#Text=That singular smoky sparkle , at once a confusion and a transparency , which is the strange secret of the Thames , was changing more and more from its grey to its glittering extreme as the sun climbed to the zenith over Westminster , and two men crossed Westminster Bridge .

#Text=One man was very tall and the other very short ; they might even have been fantastically compared to the arrogant clock-tower of Parliament and the humbler humped shoulders of the Abbey , for the short man was in clerical dress .
#Text=The official description of the tall man was M. Hercule Flambeau , private detective , and he was going to his new offices in a new pile of flats facing the Abbey entrance .

#Text=The official description of the short man was the Reverend J. Brown , attached to St. Francis Xavier ’s Church , Camberwell , and he was coming from a Camberwell deathbed to see the new offices of his friend .
#Text=The building was American in its sky-scraping altitude , and American also in the oiled elaboration of its machinery of telephones and lifts .

#Text=But it was barely finished and still understaffed ; only three tenants had moved in ; the office just above Flambeau was occupied , as also was the office just below him ; the two floors above that and the three floors below were entirely bare .
#Text=But the first glance at the new tower of flats caught something much more arresting .
#Text=Save for a few relics of scaffolding , the one glaring object was erected outside the office just above Flambeau ’s .
#Text=It was an enormous gilt effigy of the human eye , surrounded with rays of gold , and taking up as much room as two or three of the office windows .
#Text=“ What on earth is that ? ” asked Father Brown , and stood still .
#Text=“ Oh , a new religion , ” said Flambeau , laughing ;
#Text=“ one of those new religions that forgive your sins by saying you never had any .
#Text=Rather like Christian Science , I should think .
#Text=The fact is that a fellow calling himself Kalon ( I do n’t know what his name is , except that it ca n’t be that ) has taken the flat just above me .
#Text=I have two lady typewriters underneath me , and this enthusiastic old humbug on top .
#Text=He calls himself the New Priest of Apollo , and he worships the sun . ”
#Text=“ Let him look out , ” said Father Brown .
#Text=“ The sun was the cruellest of all the gods .
#Text=But what does that monstrous eye mean ? ”
#Text=“ As I understand it , it is a theory of theirs , ” answered Flambeau , “ that a man can endure anything if his mind is quite steady .
#Text=Their two great symbols are the sun and the open eye ; for they say that if a man were really healthy he could stare at the sun . ”
#Text=“ If a man were really healthy , ” said Father Brown , “ he would not bother to stare at it . ”
#Text=“ Well , that ’s all I can tell you about the new religion , ” went on Flambeau carelessly .
#Text=“ It claims , of course , that it can cure all physical diseases . ”
#Text=“ Can it cure the one spiritual disease ? ” asked Father Brown , with a serious curiosity .
#Text=“ And what is the one spiritual disease ? ” asked Flambeau , smiling .
#Text=“ Oh , thinking one is quite well , ” said his friend .
#Text=Flambeau was more interested in the quiet little office below him than in the flamboyant temple above .
#Text=He was a lucid Southerner , incapable of conceiving himself as anything but a Catholic or an atheist ; and new religions of a bright and pallid sort were not much in his line .
#Text=But humanity was always in his line , especially when it was good-looking ;
#Text=moreover , the ladies downstairs were characters in their way .
#Text=The office was kept by two sisters , both slight and dark , one of them tall and striking .
#Text=She had a dark , eager and aquiline profile , and was one of those women whom one always thinks of in profile , as of the clean-cut edge of some weapon .
#Text=She seemed to cleave her way through life .
#Text=She had eyes of startling brilliancy , but it was the brilliancy of steel rather than of diamonds ; and her straight , slim figure was a shade too stiff for its grace .
#Text=Her younger sister was like her shortened shadow , a little greyer , paler , and more insignificant .
#Text=They both wore a business-like black , with little masculine cuffs and collars .
#Text=There are thousands of such curt , strenuous ladies in the offices of London , but the interest of these lay rather in their real than their apparent position .

#Text=For Pauline Stacey , the elder , was actually the heiress of a crest and half a county , as well as great wealth ; she had been brought up in castles and gardens , before a frigid fierceness ( peculiar to the modern woman ) had driven her to what she considered a harsher and a higher existence .
#Text=She had not , indeed , surrendered her money ; in that there would have been a romantic or monkish abandon quite alien to her masterful utilitarianism .
#Text=She held her wealth , she would say , for use upon practical social objects .
#Text=Part of it she had put into her business , the nucleus of a model typewriting emporium ; part of it was distributed in various leagues and causes for the advancement of such work among women .
#Text=How far Joan , her sister and partner , shared this slightly prosaic idealism no one could be very sure .
#Text=But she followed her leader with a dog-like affection which was somehow more attractive , with its touch of tragedy , than the hard , high spirits of the elder .
#Text=For Pauline Stacey had nothing to say to tragedy ; she was understood to deny its existence .
